results.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
results.title: Biden Signs Gun Bill Into Law, Ending Years of Stalemate
results.abstract: The bill is the most significant gun measure to clear Congress in nearly three decades, though it falls short of more restrictive gun control proposals that Democrats favor.

media.caption: President Biden signed into law the bipartisan gun bill before leaving for Europe. “God willing, it’s going to save a lot of lives,” he said.
media.copyright: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times

results.byline: By Emma Goldberg, Lora Kelley and Emily Flitter
results.title: Here are the companies that will cover travel expenses for employee abortions.
results.abstract: A handful of companies have committed to helping their employees access abortion services.

media.caption: Demonstrators gathered outside the Supreme Court on Friday. With abortion rights now overturned on the federal level, there is more pressure for companies to respond.
media.copyright: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Content Type: Personal Profile;Abortion;Pregnancy and Childbirth;Dating and Relationships;Men and Boys;Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)
results.title: The Voices of Men Affected by Abortion
results.abstract: In light of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, advocates from all sides of the issue have called for men to be part of the conversation. The Times heard from hundreds who wanted to share their stories.

media.copyright:
Clockwise from left: Richard Beaven,
James Jackman, Peyton Fulford and Vanessa Leroy for The New York Times

results.title: The Man Most Responsible for Ending Roe Worries That It Could Hurt His Party

results.title: June 24, 2022: The Day Chief Justice Roberts Lost His Court
results.abstract: Outflanked by five impatient and ambitious justices to his right, the chief justice has become powerless to pursue his incremental approach.

results.title: F.B.I. Raids Orlando Museum and Removes Basquiat Paintings
results.abstract: All 25 works in the museum’s Jean-Michel Basquiat exhibition were seized by the F.B.I. An affidavit called into question their origin and their authenticity.

media.caption: Law enforcement personnel outside the Orlando Museum of Art on Friday, June 24. Earlier, F.B.I. agents seized 25 paintings said by the museum to be by Jean-Michel Basquiat following questions raised about their authenticity.
media.copyright: Willie J. Allen Jr./Orlando Sentinel, via Associated Press
